description: We recently updated one of our test clusters, and the default scheduler changed to FilterScheduler. This cause problems because free_ram_mb for each of our (havily oversubscribed) compute notes was a negative number, which means the RamFilter didn't allow instances to schedule any more. I haven't been able to quickly identify why free_ram_mb was negative, but I'll circle back around and provide more details when I can.
title: FilterScheduler expects free_ram_mb to be a positive number

comments.content: We recently updated one of our test clusters, and the default scheduler changed to FilterScheduler. This cause problems because free_ram_mb for each of our (havily oversubscribed) compute notes was a negative number, which means the RamFilter didn't allow instances to schedule any more. I haven't been able to quickly identify why free_ram_mb was negative, but I'll circle back around and provide more details when I can.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~mikal

comments.content:
If you want to allow instances to be scheduled on oversubscribed host machines you could always disable the Ram filter entirely.

Try adding this to your nova.conf file:

scheduler_default_filters=AvailabilityZoneFilter,ComputeFilter

** the default scheduler_default_filters value in Nova has a RamFilter included as well.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~dan-prince

comments.content: Michael - does dprince's suggestion work for you?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~markmc

comments.content: We cannot solve the issue you reported without more information. Could you please provide the requested information ?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content: This bug lacks the necessary information to effectively reproduce and fix it, therefore it has been closed. Feel free to reopen the bug by providing the requested information and set the bug status back to ''New''.
